page.title: 04MAIDSTONE PRISON
page.content: Maidstone prison was built on its present site in 1811-18. The architect was Daniel Alexander. The prison is surrounded by a ragstone wall on three sides (probably from the Boughton Quarries) and on the fourth side by the County Hall, which was originally built as a Sessions house in 1828. The prison was built as a County Jail and House of Correction, costing #22,000. Prisoners were transported overseas through tunnels via the River Medway. The modern prison of 13 acres is an adult male long-term training prison for category "B" prisoners. It provides vocational training programmes (welding bricklaying, printing, tailoring etc..) Education is given from general education up to Open University level. Inmate links with the town include a Braille unit and work with older folk, children and Cheshire Homes.
